Stevens Model 311 12 ga Series H Double Barrel Shotgun SxS
2 3/4" / 3.00" Shells
28" Barrel

In great condition and well taken care of.  Shoots and looks great.


I found this on the web which I found to be interesting....

The 311-h in 12 ga x 2-3/4" & 3" has a full choke barrel on the left, and a mod choke barrel on the right. Most fixed choke double-barreled shotguns larger than .410 have different chokes on the barrels, so you can shoot for the pattern you need for the range you need. If you look really closely, you will notice on the 311 series H, one of the last 311 series made, that they even regulated the barrels for different ranges, and that your full choke barrel points slightly higher than the mod choke, to center the pattern on the sight post at a longer range.  Cool, huh?

title: For Sale:  Hornady 366 auto shotshell reloader
postcontent:
If you're an avid trap, skeet, sporting clays shooter or devoted bird hunter, what could be better than a day in the field? Certainly not a day at your reloading table. Which is why Hornady created the 366 Auto, a machine that cranks out low-cost reloads in a hurry, so you can spend more time shooting. It's easy. All you do is set in an empty case and wad, and then pull the operating lever. Everything else is done for you-automatically. Every stroke turns out a precisely crimped shell, fully resized to factory dimensions.

The 366 Auto features full-length resizing, automatic primer feed, swing-out wad guide, three-stage Taper-Loc crimping, automatic advance to the next station, automatic ejection and one primer tube filler. Additional die sets are available in 12, 20, and 28 gauge.

This Hornady 366 reloading press is sized for 12 Ga.

Like new condition. Comes with everything pictured including spare parts, 75ish pounds of shot, wads and hulls. Hulls are not pictured but I have one or two large bags.




Here is link to the manual so you can see how it works.
http://www.hornady.com/assets/files/manuals-current/shotshell-reloading/366_loader.pdf

title: For Sale/Trade:  Webley Mark I Revolver
postcontent:
Up for sale/trade is a Webley Mark I revolver, Not a Mark I* or I**, so this is an example of the earliest model of Webley.
Some minor pitting in places but no obvious surface rust. Blued finish.
Lockup seems to be tight.
Proof marks everywhere..serial number of "1022" and all the serial numbered parts match.

It's been shaved for .45 ACP use(with moon clips) rather than the original .455 Webley cal. The very bottom edge of the serial numbers on the rear face of the cylinder are missing and the cylinder face has no proof marks on it at all.
I think the the barrel has been cut and the front sight moved. Looks to be a pretty good job if so. I understand that the barrel cutting and shaved cylinders were pretty common when they were imported to make them more palatable to the US market as the original .455 Webley cal wasn't really available here.

The star extractor does not snap back into place when you open the gun, the extractor stays in the "up" position until you start to close the gun, then it lowers. I have not disassembled it so it could be just dirt/gunk. The gun can still be loaded/fired regardless. 

UPDATE - Ive had numerous emails from other Webley owners that it's most likely dirt/gunk causing the above. You'll mileage may vary..I'll leave it to the new owner.

The Mark I Webleys were last made in the 1890's, so since it was made pre 1899, it can be bought/sold/mailed, etc. without a FFL as it's considered "antique". Includes brown leather holster. This is the epitome of the classic British pistol at the height of their empire. Or if you just want to look like Sherlock Holmes. The pictures are a little deceiving...this is a big, heavy pistol, with a huge .45 cal bore. :)

I'm looking to trade it outright for a modern firearm, or asking $375.00 cash as well. Please feel free to email with any questions or request pics of specific areas of the pistol. Thanks for looking.

title: For Sale:  REDUCED!!! RARE-CUSTOM SIG .22 Mosquito CERAKOTE
postcontent:
I have a SIG .22 mosquito that has a custom CERAKOTE job on it. For you that don't know, CERAKOTE is like DURACOAT except it has been proven to be more resistant, durable, and all together tougher. Check it out if you don't believe me-
(http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ksj-XJzVQik)  

It is a duotone job with the "graphite black" on the slide and I think it was the "sniper grey" on the frame, giving it the reverse two tone look. It was done professionally by the company so no worries about it being an amateur job. It cost me 150.00 to get both the slide and frame CERAKOTE'ed, and then another 30.00 (180.00 total without shipping) for the duotone because they were different colors. Looks completely natural, no flaw in the workmanship at all. The only way to tell that it is coated is to hold it up to a regular reverse two tone SIG. It's a beautiful piece of art and workmanship. Flawless. Has an extremely low round count through it. Has been cleared and oiled ever time it has been shot. I'd like 600 for this piece of art, but I need the money so I am bringing it down to 500.00 and even though it would probably break my heart I might be persuaded to bring it down a bit more. I bought the gun for 380.00 total and then put the 180.00 coat on it. So a 560.00 deal package for 500.00. Seems very reasonable for to me. Make me an offer and we can see what we can do.

title: For Sale:  Automatic August 2012 - Machine Gun Shoot
postcontent:
When someone tells you they are going to “AA”, how do you feel? Do you encourage them? Do you feel sorry for them? Do you condemn them? At Gun Envy, when someone mentions “AA”, we get all EXCITED!!! Because at Gun Envy, “AA” stands for “AUTOMATIC AUGUST”!!! Thats right, on August 5th, 2012, Gun Envy will host our first annual Automatic August Machine Gun Shoot in Harrisburg, OH!!!!

Tickets will be on sale soon, and must be purchased in advance for a specified time block. No tickets will be sold the day of the event, and no walk ons will be permitted. You are free to book your time block after tickets are paid for. The cost will be $35 per person, for a one hour block. That time block will include a range orientation/safety brief.

Tickets do not include ammunition, which must be purchased on site at the range. Ammo will be sold in magazines or belts, for whatever gun you want to shoot. Shoot all you want within the block for which you purchased your ticket. Ammo prices will be posted soon. We will be set up to take cash or credit cards at the range.

Concessions will be available on site, if you wish to purchase food/drinks/tshirts/ etc…

As it stands now, the weapon lineup will be as follows, and will include multiples of most weapons:

M4
AK47
AK74
MP5
Sten MKIII
M249 (SAW)
MK46 (closed bolt select fire SAW)
1919 Machine Gun

Weapons lineup subject to change without notice.

Tickets available in the store and on www.automaticaugust.com


Mark your calendars folks, on August 5, 2012 its goin down on SUNDAY SUNDAY SUNDAY!!!!!!!!

title: For Sale:  custom rock river ar15
postcontent: Alright what we have here is one bad ass AR. It started out as a rock river lar15 which then had the following "extra touches". The barrel has been trued and shroud tensioned to the gas block like volquartsen match rifles and pistols which gives the affect of HBAR or heavy bull barrel WITHOUT THE WEIGHT! The rifle also sports rock rivers two stage national match trigger which is consistently at 2.5 pounds if i remember correctly. the furniture on the rifle starting from the rear is a ACE tubular stock which gives you a good compact feel and short length of pull. The handguard system is a VLTOR which as we all know isnt cheap. The rear of the rail was shortened for the rifle allowing the use of iron sights which isnt typical with this rail. The sights on the rifle are rear LMT match sight and a Truglo green illuminated sight. All in all you get a VERY nice package im just looking for something different so out with this one. And yes the rifle is extremely accurate one MOA isnt a problem once so ever. Any questions just leave a email or call or text at REDACTED5.

title: For Sale:  Springfield XDS .45 ACP NIB
postcontent:
Brand New Springfield XDS (45ACP) $675.00

Introducing the XD-S. Superior innovation in the palm of your hand. This slim, powerful addition to the XD line delivers all the performance of a.45 expertly engineered to fit in any size hand. At only 1" wide, the XD-Sfits as perfectly into your concealed-carry strategy as it does in the palm of your hand. And with it, you get the power of a .45 with superior control and comfort without sacrificing important safety features. The unique combination of an ultra-slim profile paired with enhanced performance point-and-shoot features allows you to shoot accurately without having to adjust your wrist giving you greater control. Prepare to be impressed with the single-position Picatinny rail that puts lights and lasers within easy reach. With an eye toward detail, the low-profile rear and fiber-optic front sights are specifically designed to allow you to quickly zero in on your target. This powerful pistol includes the Ultra Safety Assurance (USA)Action Trigger System, loaded chamber indicator and grip safety. In addition, the XD-S offers a top-of-the-line, enhanced secure grip texturefor greater control and usability. The XD-S disassembles just like the XD, however, with the XD-S, the disassembly lever cannot be manipulated with a magazine in the pistol. Additionally, when the disassembly lever is up, a magazine cannot be inserted into the pistol.

title: For Sale:  German Nazi Mauser K98k Kriegsmodell bnz 4 code late war 8mm
postcontent:
EMAIL FOR MANY MORE PICTURES

FOR SALE an interesting G.I. bringback rifle from the WWII era, not an import. It was sporterized by the G.I. and used as a hunting rifle.

The stock, barrel, receiver are matching numbers 9628, although the receiver does not appear to be stamped with a serial number (?), it is no doubt the original receiver. Receiver code is bnz. 4 1944 Steyr-Daimler-Puch AG, Steyr

Acceptance stamps on side or receiver are WaA77-WaA77-WaA623 Steyr Austria. Steyr-Daimler-Puch A.G., Werk Steyr, Österreich (bnz) : (K98k : 1940 - 44)

Barrel stamp is cy-bnz shield-WaA623 Steyr-Daimler-Puch A.G., Werk Steyr, Österreich (bnz) : (K98k, VK.98, MP40 : 1940 - 45)

rear sight base, slider, and upper sight ladder are WaA77 and the s/n matches the barrel on the sight base, sight ladder, and sight slider with 9628 on the bottom sight base, top sight ladder, and slider.

Lower sight tube base has side stamps WaA77-WaA77

Front sight base has barely visible WaA77 facing forward.

BOLT is early OBERNDORF stamped P74 on bottom root of bolt handle, and also stamped P74 on the extractor retaining collar. The P74 proof is usually seen on M-O S/42 K's and very early S/42 G's. You also see P74 proofed rear sight bases and rear sight parts on Gew 98m's from time to time. The Germans used whatever they had on hand to make a serviceable rifle by 1944.

the trigger guard and follower are stamped WaA135
Mauser Werke K.G., Oberndorf-am-Neckar, Nordrhein-Westfalen

Bolt shround is stamped ghn
	Carl Ullrich & Co. Metallwarenfabrik, Oberschönau, Thüringen

http://home.scarlet.be/p.colmant/subcontractors.htm

cocking piece stamped "e"
	Hermann Köhler A.G. Nähmaschinenfabrik, Altenburg, Thüringen

safety stamped "m"
	Limbacher Maschinenfabrik, Bach-u. Winter, Limbach, Sachsen

serial numbers on shroud, safety, cocking piece, firing pin are 465 matching each other.

serial numbers on bolt and extractor match each other with 4548 and 48

has the original and correct cupped buttplate without takedown hole, there was takedown washers and bushing in the stock, but they were removed and filled when sporterized.

The fore end and wrist have been extensively hand checkered and the design is actually quite good.

The right side buttstock has an engraved MOUNTAIN LION with long tail standing on a rock looking down, with whiskers and paws.

The barrel condition is EXCELLENT LIKE NEW. The rifling is crisp from chamber to crown.

Find a K98 stock. upper handguard, and bands, and drop this in, you will have a nice bnz4 rifle. NOT DRILLED AND TAPPED for scope.

title: For Sale/Trade:  PTR-91 GI model, w/ Millet DMS-1 and PEPR scope mount + 9 magazines
postcontent:
F/S a PTR-91 GI in like new condition. The GI model is designed with slightly looser tolerances to accommodate all the crappy .308/762x51mm you get for cheap or steal from the range.

I've fired 120 rounds of Lake City M80 reloads (VERY clean-shooting), 40+ rounds of Silver Bear, and 40 rounds of Wolf. Never any FTF, FTE, malfunctions, etc. Shoots reasonably accurate--especially as advertised. I think my best was actually from the Silver Bear (2 inch group at a hundred yards from a bench)

I have 9 20rd magazines total for it, 1 PTR-91 Inc mag, and 8 West German surplus aluminum mags that have been cleaned of cosmoline and have no rust on the followers. 

The DMS-1/mount is optional, it's a damn good 1-4x scope and I could use it on any of my other guns. If you want it without the optic then I'll bring it down to 1000.

I will accept cash or discrete PayPal. Obviously, must have proof of existence on this planet and be willing to sign a receipt.

title: For Sale:  F/S Inch-pattern FAL L1A1
postcontent:
This is a Century (Oh no!) build FAL that belonged to a member of Aurora PD. The bullet guide is a widow's peak variety, NOT the dreaded U-shaped. The headspace is actually correct, and the barrel was properly timed by a gunsmith. The bolt carrier group and receiver DO NOT have matching serial numbers. Also, I'm not sure what parts kit was used, but everything looks peachy-keen down there and it runs just great.

The gunsmith I got it appraised from told me I should get $800 out of this but... I didn't get it for that much. $700 is very fair for a rifle in this good condition. I've shot a little over 100 rounds through it (Lake City M80 reloads, as in the PTR I am selling), and it DID have a double feed because I had the gas system let ALL the way out. 

Why am I selling it? Two reasons: the adjustable gas system has only two settings, vice the normal 8 of premium builds. This doesn't really matter so much, but I like to have the best. Also, there is no last-round bolt hold-open feature. Evidently this was an intentional drawback by the manufacturers built-in to the Sporter variety, as stated in the manual it came with.  

Comes with 1 20rd metric magazine. Metric magazines work just fine.

"Cash is king" but I can also take discrete PayPal, provided there is a real life meet-up (I'd rather a prospective buyer actually look at it and buy with some confidence that this isn't a POS frankengun)

title: For Sale:  Lee 1000 progressive press set up for 9mm, accessories, reloading manual, reloading table
postcontent:
Lee 1000 progressive press.  Current set up for 9mm.  Change the carrier and you can load any hand gun caliber, and I think you maybe able to get a carrier for 223 as well (please check with Lee).  The one I have for sale is the exact one shown here: http://leeprecision.com/pro-1000-9mm-luger.html  I built a stable table for it as seen in the pictures.  If they are upside down sorry, I can email pics.  I have everything boxed up, but the instructions and info are all online.  Over the winter I made about 1000 rounds, and it was fun.  However, I'm moving several states away, and this didn't make the cut.  The table is small enough for a corner of a garage or basement without causing too much clutter.  As you can see I removed the reloader but it is predrilled for the machine for stable reloading.  
I will also include the Lyman reloading manual seen here: http://www.amazon.com/Lyman-Reloading-Handbook-49th-Edition/dp/B001FBFW6U/ref=sr_1_4?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=REDACTED&sr=1-4&keywords=reloading+manual
I'll throw in a bunch of range pick up 9mm cases, quality electronic scale, and also the vibrating case tumbler with plenty of (i think) crushed walnut husks for cleaning cases.  It can fit anywhere between 150-200 cases with ease.  Turn it on and leave it for a few and come back to bright shiny cases.  
I spent about 300-350 for this set up plus the time to build it.  The lee press works well, you just have to get it tuned in, but once it is set up perfectly, you'll have some great bullets for the range in no time flat.  There are also plenty of videos on youtube to help set up.  
Cash, local, you pick up in Hilliard.
